question_summary: Can principal claim unpaid money after 25 years from a 2000 GPA sale deed transaction?
question_detail: Registered sale deed executed through GPA in 2000 for 4 lakh rupees (cash payment documented). Principal filed possession case in 2006, withdrew in 2019. Now threatening to file case for unpaid amount after 25 years. GPA holder is deceased. Current owner in possession for 25 years with all taxes paid.
answer_summary: Principal's claim is time-barred. Fight the case confidently - her legal position is extremely weak due to 22-year limitation bar and adverse possession rights.

answer_detail.recommendation: Let her file case. No need to settle due to pressure tactics.

key_legal_issues.explanation: Money recovery claims have 3-year limitation from debt due date. Transaction in 2000 means limitation expired around 2003 - claim is time-barred by 22 years.
25 years of continuous possession, paying taxes, with proper documentation establishes adverse possession rights (12-year requirement satisfied twice over).
Sale deed mentioning consideration as received creates strong presumption of payment.
Current owner purchased from valid GPA holder. Any payment dispute is between principal and attorney, not current owner.
Withdrawn possession case provides no protection for money recovery claim - different causes of action. Order II Rule prevents reagitating same dispute.

answer_detail.defensive_strategy: Maintain documentation of continuous 25-year possession, all tax payments, and original sale deed showing consideration received.

legal_references: Limitation Act - 3 year limitation for money recovery
Adverse Possession - 12 year requirement
Order II Rule CPC - Withdrawal of suit
Order 23 Rule 2 CPC - Plaintiff bound by limitation
Section 14 - No benefit for voluntary withdrawals
expert_consensus: Fight confidently - principal's legal position is hopeless

question_summary: What is the sequence of cross-examination in civil suits? Can evidence be recorded in English in Tamil Nadu quasi-judicial bodies?

question_detail.q1: After plaintiff presents evidence, does cross-examination of plaintiff or defendant come first? (No witnesses, only plaintiff and 2 defendants)
question_detail.q2: In Tamil Nadu quasi-judicial body, chairperson insists on recording evidence in Tamil despite request for English. Can Order 18 Rule 9 CPC be cited to have evidence recorded in English?

answer_summary.q1: Cross-examination of plaintiff comes FIRST after plaintiff's evidence. Defendant cross-examines plaintiff before presenting own case.
answer_summary.q2: Tamil is mandatory in Tamil Nadu lower courts unless all parties consent to English. Order 18 Rule 9 CPC gives discretionary power but requires consent of all parties.

cross_examination_sequence: 1. Plaintiff examines himself (files proof affidavit, marks exhibits)

language_recording_rules.tamil_nadu_position: Tamil is official language for subordinate courts and quasi-judicial bodies under Tamil Nadu Official Language Act, 1956 (Section 4-A)
order_18_rule_9_requirements: Judge/presiding officer must be conversant with English
language_recording_rules.current_practice: Subordinate courts record in Tamil; High Court uses English; Some tribunals (NCLT, RERA, CAT) use English
action_steps: File formal written application citing Order 18 Rule 9 CPC
Request English recording with proper justification
alternatives_if_tamil_mandated: Request English deposition be annexed to record
Request Tamil translation shown for confirmation before signing
Ensure written statements in English attached to official record

legal_references: Order 18 Rules 1-2 CPC - Evidence procedure
Order 18 Rule 4 CPC - Affidavit in evidence
Order 18 Rule 9 CPC - When evidence may be taken in English
Tamil Nadu Official Language Act, 1956 - Section 4-A
Article 348(1)(b) - English in court proceedings
Article 350 - Language rights
expert_consensus: Cross-examination of plaintiff comes first; Tamil is mandatory unless all parties consent to English

question_summary: Can divorced mother omit father's name from child's 10th standard mark sheet when father relinquished all rights?
question_detail: Mother divorced via mutual consent (2017, Madras HC). Ex-husband relinquished all rights to child in settlement, remarried immediately, provided no support. Mother raised child alone since birth. School insists on including father's name from birth certificate in 10th mark sheet. Mother wants to exclude father's name.
answer_summary: YES - Mother CAN legally exclude father's name. Strong Supreme Court precedents support this position when father has abandoned family or relinquished rights.

answer_detail.legal_position: No law in India requires father's name in educational records, especially when father abandoned family or relinquished rights through divorce

key_supreme_court_precedents.ruling: Birth certificate can be issued in mother's name alone. Authorities cannot force father's name disclosure. Forcing disclosure violates privacy and dignity.
Parental details in educational certificates can be corrected/altered. Right to identity, dignity, privacy under Articles 14, 19, 21. 'Law cannot treat mother as lesser parent.'

key_supreme_court_precedents.case: Shalu Nigam v. Regional Passport Officer (Delhi HC, 2016)
key_supreme_court_precedents.ruling: No legal requirement for father's name in official documents where father has abdicated responsibility.

answer_detail.cbse_circular: CBSE/Coord/AS(C)/112576/2018 confirms name of EITHER parent or guardian may be entered. Where single parent applies, name of either father OR mother shall be recorded.

documents: Divorce decree showing father's rights relinquishment
Request only mother's name as parent/guardian

action_plan.action: If refused - Escalate to District Education Officer
If still denied - File Writ Petition

details.type: Writ Petition for Mandamus under Article 226
grounds: Father relinquished rights in court-approved divorce decree
Insisting on father's name violates privacy, dignity, equality (Article 21)
details.timeline: 1-2 weeks filing, 1-2 months interim orders, 3-6 months final orders

legal_references: ABC v. State (NCT) - AIR 2015 SC 2569
Jigya Yadav v. CBSE (2021) 7 SCC 535
Shalu Nigam v. Regional Passport Officer (Delhi HC, 2016)
K.V. Venkatesh v. State of Karnataka (2018)
Rameshwari Devi v. State of NCT of Delhi (2017)
Articles 14, 19, 21 - Fundamental Rights
Article 226 - Writ Petition
Right to Education Act, 2009
CBSE Circular CBSE/Coord/AS(C)/112576/2018
expert_consensus: Mother CAN remove father's name - strong legal precedents support position. File writ petition if needed.
conflicting_opinions: Some experts believe biological father's name should be mentioned, but this view is NOT supported by Supreme Court precedents

question_summary: How to obtain condonation for delay in holding AGM of registered society due to auditor's delay?
question_detail: Club registered under Tamil Nadu Societies Registration Act, 1975 could not hold AGM by September 30, 2025 due to auditor not providing audited accounts. Informed local Registrar of Societies in advance. What steps to obtain delay condonation?
answer_summary: YES - Delay condonation is possible and likely to be granted. Auditor's delay is valid reason. Proactive notification to Registrar demonstrates good faith.

legal_framework.section_15_1_proviso: Registrar may extend time for AGM by up to 3 months for special reason
legal_framework.section_26_3_rule_25: AGM must be held within 6 months from financial year close (by Sept 30 if FY ends March 31). Registrar has discretionary power to extend/condone delay for valid reasons

details.address_to: District Registrar of Societies, Tamil Nadu
details.subject: Request for condonation of delay in convening Annual General Body Meeting under Section 26(3) of TN Societies Registration Act, 1975
content_include: Mention of earlier intimation to Registrar
Undertaking to file returns immediately after AGM

step_by_step_process.title: Pass Executive Committee Resolution
step_by_step_process.details: Hold committee meeting, pass resolution authorizing delay condonation request, get signatures from all committee members, attach to application

step_by_step_process.title: Gather Supporting Documents
documents: Letter from auditor explaining delay (if available)
Form VII (managing committee list if changes)

step_by_step_process.title: Submit Application
step_by_step_process.method: File physically at District Registrar (Societies) office or use Form GNL-1. Obtain acknowledgement with seal, date, and inward number

step_by_step_process.title: Registrar's Review
step_by_step_process.process: Registrar verifies explanation and documents, may call for clarification, checks if reasons are genuine and beyond control, issues written condonation order, permits AGM on later date (usually 30-60 days extension)

step_by_step_process.title: After Receiving Condonation
actions: Conduct AGM immediately on approved date
Present audited accounts, annual report, auditor's report

step_by_step_process.title: File Annual Returns
file_with_registrar: Updated Form VII if office-bearers changed

consequences_without_condonation: Violation under Section 36 of the Act
Office-bearers can be penalized or disqualified
Registrar may appoint authorized officer to convene meeting

legal_references: Tamil Nadu Societies Registration Act, 1975 - Section 15(1) Proviso
Tamil Nadu Societies Registration Act, 1975 - Section 26(3)
Tamil Nadu Societies Registration Act, 1975 - Section 36 (penalties)
Tamil Nadu Societies Registration Rules, 1978 - Rule 25
Form VI - Annual Return
Form VII - List of Managing Committee
Form GNL-1 - General application form
expert_consensus: Delay condonation will likely be granted - proceed with formal application citing auditor delay
reason_for_confidence: Valid reason (auditor delay beyond control), advance intimation showing good faith, standard provision exists, commonly granted
